message.content: This question requires knowledge about the causes of pollution. Option (A) is a known cause of pollution as styrofoam is non-biodegradable and contributes to waste. Option (C) is also a known cause of pollution as car emissions release harmful pollutants into the atmosphere. Option (D) is another known cause of pollution as cigarette smoke contains numerous toxic chemicals. Option (B) is least likely to cause pollution as pedaling forward does not release any harmful pollutants into the environment.

This question requires basic knowledge about the causes of pollution. Option (B) is least likely to cause pollution because pedaling forward, presumably on a bicycle, does not emit harmful pollutants into the environment. Option (A) is incorrect because using styrofoam can contribute to pollution, as it is not biodegradable and can end up in landfills or in waterways. Option (C) is incorrect because driving cars can release pollutants such as carbon dioxide and nitrogen oxides. Option (D) is incorrect because smoking cigarettes releases harmful chemicals into the air, contributing to air pollution.

This question requires knowledge about the causes of pollution. Option (B) is the least likely cause of pollution. Using styrofoam (option A) can contribute to pollution because it is not biodegradable. Driving cars (option C) can cause air pollution through emissions. Smoking cigarettes (option D) releases harmful chemicals into the air. Option (B) is incorrect because pedaling forward does not inherently contribute to pollution.

To solve this question, we need to identify the option that is least likely to cause pollution. 

Option (A) states that using styrofoam can cause pollution. Styrofoam is a non-biodegradable material that can contribute to environmental pollution if not properly disposed of. This makes option (A) a possible cause of pollution.

Option (B) states that pedaling forward is least likely to cause pollution. Pedaling forward refers to riding a bicycle, which is a form of transportation that does not emit any pollutants. Bicycles are environmentally friendly and do not contribute to air or noise pollution. This makes option (B) the correct answer.

Option (C) states that driving cars can cause pollution. Cars emit greenhouse gases and pollutants that contribute to air pollution. This makes option (C) a possible cause of pollution.

Option (D) states that smoking cigarettes can cause pollution. Cigarette smoke contains harmful chemicals and pollutants that contribute to air pollution. This makes option (D) a possible cause of pollution.

Based on the explanations above, option (B) is the least likely to cause pollution as it does not contribute to any form of pollution.
